Award.AwardTitle: Adaptive Laser Shock Micro-Forming Process and Metrology

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports fundamental optics science research on laser matter interaction to establish a parallel laser micro-forming manufacturing technology. Specifically, the research will use adaptive optical technology to generate multiple laser beams with arbitrary laser beam profile and energy distribution to perform rapid three-dimensional laser shock micro-forming on multiple micro workpieces simultaneously. Using the adaptive laser beam shaping tool and multi-resolution molecular mechanic simulation approach, laser-induced shock wave interaction with micro- and nano-mechanical structures will be studied to gain better understanding on laser-induced defect initiation, propagation, and distribution to improve three-dimensional laser micro-forming manufacturing outcome.

The new laser shock manufacturing scheme developed from this research has potential to completely overhaul the existing laser shock micro-forming manufacturing technique. It will dramatically improve manufacturing flexibility, precision, and throughput. The scientific investigation will advance scientific understanding on the interaction of laser-induced shock wave with mechanical structures at nanometer scale. The new laser shock manufacturing technology will enhance the competitiveness of the US manufacturing industry in micro-system manufacturing and assembly. This award also provides new training opportunities to US students in laser technology, manufacturing, and material engineering through new course development, extracurricular activities, and community outreach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Laser shock micro-forming is a non-thermal laser forming method that use laser-induced shockwave to modify surface properties and to adjust shapes and geometry of work pieces. In this research project, we developed an adaptive optical technique to engineer spatial profiles of the laser beam to control shapes, sizes, and locations of the laser-induced shockwaves and the resulting forming features. Using a spatial light modulator, this adaptive laser beam forming tool was used to process free-standing MEMS structures, which has led to highly uniform forming features. Shockwave simultaneously excited by multiple laser beams generated by the spatial light modulator and its effects on the micro-forming process are also studied. The research outcomes from this project shows that the adaptive-optics laser beam forming is an effective and flexible method to generate shockwave with various shapes and sizes of wavefront and at multiple locations for laser processing at microscales.

 Using the similar adaptive laser beam shaping method, a novel adaptive laser beam forming tool has been developed for two endoscopic laser surgical procedures. By sculpting the wave front of the laser, the on-target focal point, divergence, and shape of the ablation laser spot can be actively controlled in endoscopes. The laser beam can be placed anywhere within the entire field-of view of the endoscope with the click of a mouse without ever moving the tip of endoscope for surgery. Comparing with existing techniques, our innovation dramatically enhances surgical accuracy, precision, and speed, along with the irrigation visibility and maneuverability of the endoscope tip. Two laser surgical applications have been explored. These include laser beam shaping technology for endoscope laser kidney surgery, and the adaptive laser beam steering and imaging for laser-assist pacemaker/defibrillator lead extraction, a cardiovascular surgery.  

To better understand internal stress induced in work pieces by both laser additive and subtractive manufacturing processes. During the course of this project, we explored an innovative concept of sensor-fused laser manufacturing schemes. Using high-resolution distributed fiber sensor embedded in work pieces as measurement tools, this project carried out innovative applied research to measure the impacts of laser processing (both additive and subtractive) on work pieces including temperature and strain profiles with 5-mm spatial resolution.
